DOC.HEAD: Cheney Pleased with Operation of Media Pool in Dangerous Circumstances
Eds: INSERTS new 3rd-4th grafs with more reporters arriving
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Thursday he was pleased with the operation of the media pool that accompanied the U.S. invasion force to Panama, despite complaints that reporters had been kept away from the action. ``I think there was adequate coverage. I think our commanders on the scene had their priorities straight,'' said Cheney, noting that media executives had called his office demanding that the military protect reporters who were not in the pool. Later in the day, about 50 more journalists arrived in Panama with 300 expected by early Friday. Lt. Col. James Swank, a military spokesman, said the reporters would be allowed to camp out in the officers club restaurant, but by Friday night would be expected to have their own accommodations. Several non-pool photographers were killed or wounded in the action, and other journalists were taken hostage by forces loyal to ousted Panamanian strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams, sitting with Cheney in an interview with 11 newspaper and wire service journalists, acknowledged that ``we wish we could have done a better job getting people around'' on Wednesday. The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell, also said he was pleased with the operation of he pool, especially because the news organizations involved had not leaked word of the invasion in advance. ``I think it worked marvellously,'' Powell said, noting that it had not always gone well on previous occasions. The institution was created following the secret 1982 invasion of Grenada. News organizations which take part in the pool agree in advance to keep its activation a secret. ``We did what we promised you we would do and the media in the pool did what they promised they would do,'' Powell said. Pool members were collected late Tuesday night and flown to Panama with the invasion force. ``There never was any concern in my mind it would break security and it didn't,'' Powell said of the pool. Oddly enough, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater earlier Thursday had charged that a pool participant had ``divulged their participation and departure before they left here.'' He wouldn't say what organization had done so. Williams, speaking to reporters earlier, said his office had complained to field commanders because pool members had been restricted largely to interviews with U.S. embassy officials during most of the first day of the invasion. He laid the problem to ``incompetence'' and said, ``There really is no excuse for it.'' Later he said he was personally responsible for the operation of the press pool and was accepting the characterization of incompetence for himself rather than for the officers in the field. ``They've been working day and night for five days,'' he said of the Southern Command officers. Williams spoke at the close of a news conference at which top military officers also were asked why they had not taken more steps to protect U.S. reporters, who were not members of the pool, from being taken hostage at the Marriott Hotel. The spokesman and other senior Pentagon officials said the first objective of the invasion force had been to disperse the Panamanian Defense Forces and occupy their base, which they said they accomplished on Wednesday. The lives of American hostages became a prime concern for U.S. forces as the fighting died down. Williams said there were reports of an unknown number of Americans being held in three separate incidents. ``We take them all seriously,'' he said. Those held were said to include Jon Meyersohn, a CBS News television producer. U.S. troops evacuated 29 Americans and 35 foreigners, mostly Panamanians, from the Marriott Hotel in Panama City late Wednesday night, but Williams said a list of the evacuees was not available. Overall, 35,000 U.S. citizens live in Panama, and ``there are Americans scattered throughout the city,'' said Williams.
